channel.title: God and Jesus
channel.description:
Do you think there is just thing as a god and "Jesus"?
I honestly believe that there may be a god but not "Jesus".

item.title: God and Jesus
item.dc:creator: @3.65_kilos 3.65 kilos
item.description:
@3.65_kilos wrote:

xxlegitxx:

Thanks for the summary of the Gospels. And btw, no one said crucifixion was anything special. Dying on the cross in and of itself was anything special. Crucifixion was clearly nothing extraordinary; it was common enough to be the root of the word ‘excruciating.’ Jesus could have died on a rock and kept the message of the NT true… the cross is not the pivotal point of the scriptures. The point is that he was the ultimate sacrifice, the ‘lamb’ of God. The center is Jesus, not a piece of wood.

You should tell that to the Christians in my region.

Read full topic

item.title: God and Jesus
item.dc:creator: @goatee goatee
item.description:
@goatee wrote:

[quote=“juju, post:67, topic:133749”]It seems alot of people are using an argument similar to Pascal’s Wager(Live as if God exists, if he does’t you dont lose anything, if he does you get into “Heaven”).

There are several bad ides with this theory:

  • A God exists and you are worshipping the incorrect one, I’m sure a good would be tougher on someone who had worshipped the wrong God instead of being an atheist.
  • “God” doesn’t reward blind believe, he rewards skepticism.
  • You do not “truly” believe that the god you worship actually exists.

The Atheist Wager sounds alot better: “You should live your life and try to make the world a better place for your being in it, whether or not you believe in God. If there is no God, you have lost nothing and will be remembered fondly by those you left behind. If there is a benevolent God, he may judge you on your merits coupled with your commitments, and not just on whether or not you believed in him.”[/quote]

Good points. Couldn’t agree more.

Read full topic

item.title: God and Jesus
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

[quote=“Mod Adam, post:24, topic:133749”]Basically no one can be called “Christians.” Christains means Christ Like, and no one is/can be Christ like.

Btw, I do believe in God + Jesus.[/quote]

A Christian is a Christ-follower, not Christ-like. No clue where you got that notion.

MastrChief:

So god does promote violence by putting murders, criminals, etc, on this planet?

So many people don’t understand this. This world/life is simply a test. A trial. You’re really not intended to be enjoying it, but if you do, so be it. God does not promote violence. But it really doesn’t matter anyway. It’s hard to put into words, but if someone kills you, why does it matter? Your spirit lives on, and isn’t that what’s important? Death is a one-way street. It’s an inevitable part of life, so if it happens earlier, does it really matter? And whatever pain you’ll experience being murdered will probably be less than whatever you’ll experience if you live out the rest of your life. Not saying I’m fine with being murdered right now. Given the situation, all the evolution-derived mental triggers will probably force myself to attempt to save my life.

ThAt0n36Uy:

The Bible says that the ones who aren’t capable of sinning, or under stand sin, Even Accept Jesus Christ. They’re apparently on a get out of Jail free pass (e.g. Special Children, Babies, etc).

I have yet to find a Biblical reference which states that they get a free pass to heaven. Because under that clause, the best thing to do for your children would be to abort them or kill them as they are born. Hardly likely.

[quote=“jme_009, post:60, topic:133749”]Costs nothing? Hell it costs way too much in my opinion. Costs many hours of your time, donations, living a life in fear that you may go to hell for sinning, etc

Personally I’d rather spend my Sunday’s watching nascar. And it’s not as simple as “believing god just incase.” If I tried to believe in god, I would only be trying to fool myself. I simply don’t, and can’t, believe in a god. I can’t just suddenly believe in god.

I keep an open mind though, I know god is a possibility but it’s just not something I believe. I don’t want to go to heaven anyways. 80 years is enough, I don’t need eternity. I’d rather rot in the ground. [/quote]

It costs hours, true. But if you enjoy it, is it wasted any more than hours smoking a joint? Offering is always optional. And there is no need to be afraid of sinning if you understand the concept of Christianity. It’s a pity to reject something without making attempts to comprehending it first.

And church isn’t just about wasting time for the sake of wasting time. It’s about making connections with people, growing in character, and all that fun stuff. Being a Christian does not entail suddenly believing in God. As a Christian, I wonder so many times whether there is a God after all. It’s not a one-time deal, flipping a switch from ‘non-believing’ to ‘believing.’

Stating that you cannot believe in a God doesn’t sound like being open-minded, imo. 80 years of what is enough? It’s not either heaven or death. It’s heaven and hell. Rotting in the ground isn’t

[quote=“Schizzo, post:61, topic:133749”]I do believe in God and Jesus and I’m a Christian. The way I see it is, even if there isn’t a God or anything (even though I thoroughly believe there is), I’m still in perfectly good shape when I die. Whether or not I’m right or wrong about my religion, I’m ok. However, if someone’s an atheist and they’re wrong when they die, they’re going to hell for eternity.

I’d rather be an incorrect Christian than an incorrect atheist.[/quote]

Pascal’s Gambit ftl? Why apply a statistical model to Christianity? And an overly-simplified one at that.

[quote=“3.65 kilos, post:63, topic:133749”]Kinda off topic, but I wanted to add it.

The Romans feared that Jesus would lead an uprising (He had thousands of followers that would do whatever he asked). To them, he was an enemy of the state. Jesus was arrested and put on trial before Pontius Pilate, the Roman Governor. Soon afterward, Jesus was crucified.

EDIT: Also offtopic…and him dieing by means of crucifixion(sp?) was nothing special. In the Punic Wars, thousands of Carthaginians were crucified. It’s just Rome’s way of killing people.[/quote]

Thanks for the summary of the Gospels. And btw, no one said crucifixion was anything special. Dying on the cross in and of itself was anything special. Crucifixion was clearly nothing extraordinary; it was common enough to be the root of the word ‘excruciating.’ Jesus could have died on a rock and kept the message of the NT true… the cross is not the pivotal point of the scriptures. The point is that he was the ultimate sacrifice, the ‘lamb’ of God. The center is Jesus, not a piece of wood.

Read full topic

[quote=“juju, post:67, topic:133749”]It seems alot of people are using an argument similar to Pascal’s Wager(Live as if God exists, if he does’t you dont lose anything, if he does you get into “Heaven”).

There are several bad ides with this theory:

  • A God exists and you are worshipping the incorrect one, I’m sure a good would be tougher on someone who had worshipped the wrong God instead of being an atheist.
  • “God” doesn’t reward blind believe, he rewards skepticism.
  • You do not “truly” believthat the god you worship actually exists.

The Atheist Wager sounds alot better: “You should live your life and try to make the world a better place for your being in it, whether or not you believe in God. If there is no God, you have lost nothing and will be remembered fondly by those you left behind. If there is a benevolent God, he may judge you on your merits coupled with your commitments, and not just on whether or not you believed in him.”[/quote] well put

item.title: God and Jesus
item.dc:creator: @3.65_kilos 3.65 kilos
item.description:
@3.65_kilos wrote:

Kinda off topic, but I wanted to add it.

The Romans feared that Jesus would lead an uprising (He had thousands of followers that would do whatever he asked). To them, he was an enemy of the state. Jesus was arrested and put on trial before Pontius Pilate, the Roman Governor. Soon afterward, Jesus was crucified.

EDIT: Also offtopic…and him dieing by means of crucifixion(sp?) was nothing special. In the Punic Wars, thousands of Carthaginians were crucified. It’s just Rome’s way of killing people.

Read full topic

item.title: God and Jesus
item.dc:creator: @Schizzo Schizzo
item.description:
@Schizzo wrote:

I do believe in God and Jesus and I’m a Christian. The way I see it is, even if there isn’t a God or anything (even though I thoroughly believe there is), I’m still in perfectly good shape when I die. Whether or not I’m right or wrong about my religion, I’m ok. However, if someone’s an atheist and they’re wrong when they die, they’re going to hell for eternity.

I’d rather be an incorrect Christian than an incorrect atheist.

Read full topic

item.title: God and Jesus
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

ThAt0n36Uy:

Waiting for proof may be the wrong idea. You may wait to long, and miss out. My aunt always said. To accept christ, costs you nothing, but to not, costs you everything. Why not give it a try, go to church, go to a school program, like FCA. See how you like it, the people there might give you a good reason to become a Christian.

Costs nothing? Hell it costs way too much in my opinion. Costs many hours of your time, donations, living a life in fear that you may go to hell for sinning, etc

Personally I’d rather spend my Sunday’s watching nascar. And it’s not as simple as “believing god just incase.” If I tried to believe in god, I would only be trying to fool myself. I simply don’t, and can’t, believe in a god. I can’t just suddenly believe in god.

I keep an open mind though, I know god is a possibility but it’s just not something I believe. I don’t want to go to heaven anyways. 80 years is enough, I don’t need eternity. I’d rather rot in the ground.

Read full topic
